Wadsworth HS Fall Sports Tickets

To adhere to the Ohio Dept. of Health Order regarding high school sports, the maximum number of spectators at Wadsworth High School athletic venues is mandated to be the lesser of 1,500 or 15% of fixed, seated capacity outdoors and the lesser of 300 or 15% indoors. As a result of this drastically reduced number of spectators permitted at home athletic contests, the only available tickets will be sold to the parents & immediate family members of participants involved with an event, whether that is a player, cheerleader or band member. Unfortunately, no tickets will be available to the general public for this fall sports season.

shared_text:
Four Cities Compact
May 6 at 1:30 PM ·

Anyone who could use a smile and a pick me up should tune into News 5 tonight and see our Compact Senior Nursing students do a drive by parade at Pleasant View Health Care Center and Pleasant Point Assisted Living! Each senior student has had a wonderful opportunity this year to get to know a resident and learn about their life and the medical challenges they face now. Since the virus put an abrupt end to both the visits residents could receive and the students school activities it was wonderful to see them together again to wave a friendly and heartfelt hello and say thank you to one another for a great experience! We are very proud of this group of wonderful seniors and would like to thank: the Pleasant View staff, Barberton Police and Officer Marty Everhart, Reporter Emily Hamilton, Photographer Brian Sobolewski and teachers Cindy Boswell and Debbie Ritz for all their help! On a week in which we salute nurses - it is nice to see such a great group of young people well on their way to joining the profession!

April 15 at 11:49 AM ·

Although our school buildings may be closed for now, work is continuing on the Compact’s Senior Carpentry house project in Wadsworth. He also gives class assignments to them based on the work he is demonstrating. It’s not ideal but it’s a way to keep the learning happening.

Also, many thanks to Davis Door for their donation of the nice garage door! The home has 3 bedrooms, a full basement, an open floor plan, and a beautiful kitchen area! Anyone looking for a great home in Wadsworth should check it out!

Four Cities Compact
January 16 at 3:58 PM ·

Senior Compact Marketing students at WHS went GLOBAL over the past few weeks. While studying the concepts and practices of international marketing, students got the chance to research a country and investigate their business practices as well as share some delicious cuisine one might find there! As an additional component to the unit, students were part of the Postcrossings movement and sent and received postcards from all over the world. They were comparing languages, customs, traditional cultures, postage, currency, and even landmarks. The class kept track on our map of all the different locations they received cards from. The site also gave data on: how long it took for the cards to be delivered, the amount of miles the cards traveled, and current events and happenings from across the globe! It was a great way for the students to better understand the very global marketplace we live in.

Career Tech Teachers have to keep up with latest technologies that are being used in business and industry. New equipment in the Engineering and Robotics Lab at Wadsworth HS provided by Haas and SME Prime led to some heavy duty training for teachers Kip Shipley and Jason Van Kirk. In November the teachers travelled to Danville Community College in Virginia for an intense training that will help them successfully operate the lab's new CNC Milling Machine and teach their students how to use it as well. The level of learning for young Engineers in training goes much deeper when they can design a part and then actually manufacture it as would be done in typical production. Many thanks to both Mr Shipley and Mr Van Kirk for their efforts- great role models of being lifelong learners!

Once the 20 "punches" have been used, a new pass would need to be purchased. If the 20 "punches" are not all used in the winter, this pass may also be used during the spring season.

post_text: The WHS Off Broad Street Players are proud to present the musical BRIGHT STAR November 21-23 @7:30 pm in the James R McIlvaine Performing Arts Center. Inspired by a true story and featuring the Tony®-nominated score by Steve Martin and Edie Brickell, BRIGHT STAR tells a sweeping tale of love and redemption set against the rich backdrop of the American South in the 1920s and ’40s. When literary editor Alice Murphy meets a young soldier just home from World War II, he awakens her longing for the child she once lost. Haunted by their unique connection, Alice sets out on a journey to understand her past—and what she finds has the power to transform both of their lives. With beautiful melodies and powerfully moving characters, the story unfolds as a rich tapestry of deep emotion. An uplifting theatrical journey that holds you tightly in its grasp, BRIGHT STAR is as refreshingly genuine as it is daringly hopeful. Tickets are $10 for adults and $8 for students and may be purchased at the door. Parental guidance suggested. Some content may not be appropriate for children.

post_text: From the Four Cities Compact! Way to go Automotive Technologies students!
shared_text:
Four Cities Compact
October 21, 2019 at 8:26 AM ·

Here's an update for all of you Car Enthusiast out there! The Compact's Automotive Technologies Seniors (program housed at Wadsworth HS) in the class of 2019 finished the 1972 Chevy C10 Truck restoration project they did as a class project last year. Almost every bolt was turned on this truck and all the work was performed by students. All suspension and steering components were replaced. The motor was completely overhauled with new high performance upgrades. The body of the truck was removed and the frame cleaned and painted. All the truck needs now is a good paint job and it will be complete.

These class projects really help provide the students with some outstanding and unique learning opportunities and they take great pride in them.
Way to go Auto students and Mr Alexander! Congratulations on a job well done!
